name: Tuesday Tidbits
description:
“The objective of this exhibition is to take the unknown and make it known” - Khushi Bansal, Curator of The Forgotten Souvenir.

We are very excited for the next session of Tuesday Titbits, a series that explores different aspects of working in a museum. 

When you enter the MAP building on the ground floor, you will come across the new exhibition “The Forgotten Souvenir”. This month’s Tuesday Tidbits features Khushi Bansal, the curator of this exhibition, currently working as a research curator at MAP. Join us as she takes us behind the scenes to explore conceptualisation, research, and development. Khushi will also share her experiences with Museums Without Borders, discussing everything from pairings to scripting and production. Join us for these free, insightful and short sessions on life in a museum, as we look at MAP through the lenses of our team members!

This is part of our series that seeks to support youth in career research/building and acts as a space for networking for young people.

name: Male Madappana Kavya
description:
Join us for a captivating performance by Tamboori Siddaraju and his ensemble from Malavalli, in the district of Mandya, Karnataka. This renowned folk artist will be performing a mesmerising rendition of Male Madappa Kavya, the divine protector of forests, through folk songs accompanied by the tamburi (a traditional stringed instrument).

The performance uniquely preserves the spiritual and cultural essence of this folk epic, offering audiences a genuine connection to our rich cultural heritage. This is more than just a performance - it's an opportunity to experience the living heritage of Karnataka's folk traditions, preserved and presented by one of its most dedicated practitioners. 

The performance is part of BLR Hubba's sub festival, Gala Gala gaddala. 

Gala-Gala-Gaddala (#3G) is a cultural carnival celebrating Karnataka's rich heritage through music, dance, theatre, and more! Co-curated by Lekha Naidu and Jangama Collective, Bangalore for BLR Hubba, this festival embodies joy, tradition, and Karnataka's Spirit.
MAP is delighted to be a part of BLR Hubba 2024, a city-wide arts and culture festival.

name: Louis Kahn's Tiger City
description:
Join us for the screening of Louis Kahn’s Tiger City in conjunction with the exhibition Eckart Muthesius and Manik Bagh: Pioneering Modernism in India curated by Raffael Dedo Gadebusch, travelling from the Museum of Asian Art, Berlin. In this film, art historian and filmmaker Sundaram Tagore retraces the footsteps of architect Louis Kahn,  uncovering how he built the iconic and monumental parliamentary complex in war-torn Bangladesh. 

Built for the Maharaja of Indore, Yashwant Rao Holkar II, Manik Bagh (or the ‘Gem Garden’) was a residential palace designed by his friend and architect Eckart Muthesius. The exhibition marks a first in a series of shows planned on architecture, focusing on plural interpretations on the idea of “home” through 3 exhibitions planned through 2025-2026. 

The screening will feature an introduction by the director, Sundaram Tagore, and conclude with a Q&A session with the audience.

name: MAYA: Kaavad Katha
description:
Immerse yourself in the enchanting world of Maya, a contemporary revival of the Kaavad.

Experience the magic of storytelling and puppetry as Maya brings to life a series of captivating tales. Inspired by the ancient "KathaSaritaSagar" format, this performance weaves together mythical characters and timeless stories, each leading to the next in a mesmerising narrative. 

The performance will be followed by an engaging Q&A session with the artist, Akshay Gandhi to give audiences more insight into this fascinating traditional art form.
MAP is delighted to be a part of BLR Hubba 2024, a city-wide arts and culture festival.

name: Written in Dance
description:
How do the arts inspire and illuminate each other? Discover the answer to this question through an engaging conversation with acclaimed author Shoba Narayan and celebrated dancer Madhu Nataraj as they both delve into the dynamic intersections of art and dance. Exploring the syncretic magic that emerges from the cross-illumination of the arts, this discussion will reveal how the spacio-temporality of dance becomes a canvas for collaborations, sparking innovations in art, literature, and beyond.

Shoba Narayan, a James Beard Award-winning author and journalist, brings her deep insights from three decades of storytelling, global lecturing, and creative ventures. Madhu Nataraj, known for her groundbreaking choreography and interdisciplinary work, adds a dancer’s perspective to this creative dialogue. Together, they illuminate the threads that weave art forms together across time and space.

MAP is delighted to be a part of BLR Hubba 2024, a city-wide arts and culture festival.

name: Create your souvenir
description:
How do we interpret the visual records of company paintings in our contemporary world? Join us for a workshop where you can create your own miniature portrait inspired by mica paintings.

The mica paintings in our latest exhibition, The Forgotten Souvenir, represent a nearly forgotten chapter in Indian art — bridging the gap between the decline of traditional miniature paintings and the rise of photography.

After a short guided walk of the exhibition, you will learn to design and curate your own portrait. Using OHP sheets and filters, you can pick and choose the elements you would like to add to your portrait. This interactive session will engage with the mica paintings of the exhibition through the aspects of transparency and portraiture. 

 

All materials for this workshop will be provided by MAP. This workshop is for individuals above the age of 16.
